Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I was checking the first-aid kit in the back of the ambulance, making sure every bandage and vial was in place, nothing expired or missing. It was a quiet Sunday morning, the kind that usually meant a slow start at the station. My hands moved automatically, but my mind wandered. I thought about the church bells that would soon ring, calling everyone to worship. I hadn’t been to Sunday service in weeks—every time I planned to go, a call would come in, or I’d be asked to cover another shift. My pastor always said that worship was a priority, a time to gather and strengthen our faith. But here, in this ambulance, I was needed too. The city expected me to be ready, to provide care at a moment’s notice. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my duty to my patients, and my longing to be with my church family. As I closed the kit, I heard the distant sound of sirens and wondered, if the call came now, what would I choose?
